title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.45 | 15-03-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So this verse describes the Lord's departure from Hastinapura to Dwaraka after Yudhishthira had been installed as the emperor of the world after the battle of Kurukshetra.
segments.summary: This segment introduces the verse describing Krishna's departure from Hastinapura and Yudhishthira's loving request for him to stay.

segments.key_quote: This signifies that the power of King Yudhishthira was loving affection, which the Lord could not deny.
segments.summary: This segment emphasizes that Krishna is conquered by loving service and voluntarily accepts obligations from his pure devotees.

segments.key_quote: Formerly the whole planet was known as Bharatvarsha.
segments.summary: This segment explains the historical significance of Hastinapura, the prevalence of Vedic culture, and the concept of Bharatvarsha encompassing the entire planet.
This segment discusses the Mahabharata as the history of greater Bharatvarsha and Krishna's acceptance of Kunti's prayers.

segments.key_quote: If we increase our love for Krishna, we will be able to do everything.
segments.summary: This segment highlights that love for Krishna allows devotees to 'purchase' Krishna, influencing his actions.

segments.key_quote: We can purchase Krishna by love.
segments.summary: This segment uses the example of Arjuna ordering Krishna as his chariot driver to illustrate how love allows devotees to influence Krishna.

segments.key_quote: all departments of knowledge are really meant for finding out Krishna.
segments.summary: This segment explains that understanding God through Vedic study is difficult, as Krishna is veiled by Yogamaya, but all knowledge ultimately aims to find Krishna.

segments.key_quote: the purpose of all education, the purpose of studying the Vedas, the purpose of getting any knowledge, is to know Krishna.
segments.summary: This segment narrates Chaitanya Mahaprabhu's Krishna-centered teaching of grammar and concludes that the ultimate goal of all knowledge is to know Krishna for a successful life.
